You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
transformed_texts: Nestled in the heart of a sprawling metropolis, my locale is a tapestry of disparities and contrasts. Dwellings and commercial spaces intermingle in an organic, seemingly chaotic dance. The commercial district boasts an array of enterprises, from sprawling corporate offices to quaint, independent shops and eateries. The culinary and retail scene is as vibrant as can be, with major brands rubbing shoulders with mom-and-pop boutiques. These shops are not confined to malls; they line the streets, often within strolling distance of residential areas, which would otherwise be tranquil and secluded. A few greenspaces dot the landscape, often frequented by families with young ones. The community is a mosaic of cultures and identities, with a prominent LGBTQ+ hub, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a cluster of former Soviet Union refugees and immigrants. Just beyond my neighborhood's borders, there's a vibrant patchwork of ethnic enclaves like Korea Town, Chinatown, and Little Armenia. Despite their proximity, these communities are not contiguous, and navigating the city can be a challenge, with traffic and parking Woes often slowing down travel. Construction has surged in recent years, with towering apartment buildings sprouting up, yet residents' sentiments are mixed about the influx of people and vehicles. Housing options range from standalone homes to duplexes and smaller apartment complexes, providing a mix of living spaces. The neighborhood itself is a hodgepodge of ages, with many faces I barely recognize. Childhood memories of outdoor play with my neighbors are a stark contrast to today's more anonymous living.

The locality I inhabit is a unique blend of the old and the new, with a touch of the suburban charm from decades past. While most abodes are standalone units, several have been reimagined into dual-family dwellings, yet they remain attached, a testament to the evolution of architectural styles. My residence boasts a modest front yard and a compact driveway to the left, reflecting an era when suburban life epitomized the American dream. This dream, once a beacon of hope, now seems to be receding, but remnants of it endure, whispering tales of resilience to those who dwell here and those who visit. The once-hopeful residents now harbor a more sobering outlook, as the upkeep of the small yards is not what it used to be, but the driveways still bear witness to the steady presence of automobiles. Youngsters continue to engage in their games, seemingly oblivious to the world beyond their realm.

The public school, a stalwart institution with nearly a century of history, stands as a beacon for future generations while stirring nostalgic memories in the hearts of the elderly. The few churches scattered about are largely empty, but the basketball courts remain a hub of activity. Each home here, though distinct in appearance, carries an underlying sense of unity. A prominent supermarket, aptly named "Super A," is owned by a Yemeni family, the only Arab family in the neighborhood, a testament to the diversity within our community. The African American residents form the majority, and the wide streets serve as natural venues for young football enthusiasts, who pause their games only to yield to oncoming traffic.

Many long-time residents have generations of history in this area, and they regale tales of a time when everyone knew everyone. Once, a karate school flourished here, but its popularity waned when Hollywood's "Karate Kid" films lost their appeal. In its place, a pharmacy now operates, embodying the modern mentality that "drugs can fix everything." A small, unassuming movie theatre screens vintage films at discounted prices, a haven for the elderly who prefer the simplicity and nostalgia it offers. The expressway that runs through town has exits and entrances in neighboring communities, a decision that sparked a contentious debate. While the youth advocated for an exit in our town, the elders, fearing the disruption it would bring, successfully persuaded the city council to deny the request. Currently, plans are underway to build a new high school, and the community is divided over the choice of mascot. I propose a cyborg with a southern accent and a log cabin as the perfect representation of our town.

At first glance, it might be easy to overlook - a sleepy residential area tucked behind a bustling shopping strip, nothing special stands out. Yet, hidden behind the dilapidated Whole Foods and the seasonal hotels, a vibrant community thrives. The apartments, though not initially appealing, are home to a close-knit neighborhood. These complexes sit close together, like Russian nesting dolls carefully arranged, offering a slice of history in the southern state. The first apartments might have a dubious past, but those nearby reveal a different story. Across from these complexes, a quiet campus of a local community college stands, where students begin their mornings with coffee cups in hand, and gates creak open to admit them. The road intersects with another residential area, where a rehabilitation center stands proudly, offering cheery porch furniture and a lazy ceiling fan. Children play in the park, bees buzz lazily, and retirees walk their dogs. Nearby, a nail salon nestles between a swimming supply store and a sushi place. You can fill your pool, get a manicure, and enjoy hibachi chicken all in one stop. A frozen yogurt shop, popular with teens, rounds out this slice of Americana. This place is a time capsule, where change is rare, and history lingers.

As we traversed the expansive cornfields that dominated the horizon, she queried, "Where's everything?" I replied, aware of the stark openness, knowing she was unfamiliar with such vastness. She hailed from a town where the grocery store was a mere five-minute stroll from her abode, and this sight was novel to her. Her eyes widened as she took in the omnipresent cornfields. I regaled her with tales of my rural Ohio upbringing, and in that moment, she finally understood my roots.

As we drove along the two-lane country road, the water-filled quarry materialized, followed by the small subdivision where I resided. The houses, primarily brick and stucco, each boasted at least half an acre of land, meticulously maintained by their owners. In spring, vibrant annual flowers and midwestern trees transformed the landscape, while luxury Mercedes-Benz vehicles gleamed after a traditional car wash. My neighbor, a Korean man, was always present, mowing his lawn and serenading passersby from his John Deere Zero Turn mower. He was once a physician, now blending seamlessly into the grass as he hummed tunes over the mower's hum. His antics elicited chuckles from the neighbors, who appreciated his genuine nature and unique background.

Further along, we arrived at my grey, stucco home. In the side yard, geese were ample, often chased by our Terrier. Behind the house, a small stream flowed into the quarry, where bullfrogs croaked, the stream gurgled, and occasional "moos" from nearby farms echoed. Across a handcrafted wooden bridge lay an untouched sanctuary filled with wild trees, herbs, and blossoms. This was my childhood playground. From constructing treehouses to "hunting" animals (more like chasing them), there was always something to engage in and a neighbor child to join in the fun.

Winters in my small town were harsh, transforming the landscape into an arctic wonderland. The backyard became a snow-covered wilderness, with the trees shedding their vibrant leaves to reveal stark branches. When snow descended, overnight, a winter wonderland emerged. Snow angels and snowmen dotted the landscape, a result of my sister's and my snowball fights. We'd construct massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, using branches as an arsenal. In our own little snow kingdom, we'd pretend to be carefree, lost in the magic of youth.

What one must grasp about Portland, Oregon is the essence of peculiarity. The city's unofficial motto, emblazoned on the wall of a multifunction establishment that serves as a pizzeria, bar, music hall, and even a strip club, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a nostalgic reminder of the Portland of the 90s and early 2000s, a time when the city was less famous and more affordable, fostering unique and creative subcultures. To others, it is an invitation - come to Portland, where being peculiar is seen as an asset. Despite the influx of wealthy Californians and the continuous construction of condominiums for their accommodation, Portland remains peculiar. Peculiar does not mean acceptance of all, but it does mean acceptance of things beyond the norm. Peculiar does not mean a lack of modern comforts or struggles. Like the rest of the nation, we acquire most of our goods from China. There are countless ways to be abnormal, to deviate from the norm, but Portland has its share of blandness. Portland has yoga enthusiasts, hipsters, and business professionals. Perhaps peculiarity implies a more relaxed approach to it all. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we see vibrant houses, home gardens filled with flowers, herbs, and vegetables lining the streets, and, in the summer, free boxes. Free boxes traditionally contain items discarded by others, but they can also be plastic bags or boxes. They hold something extraordinary, a perfect treasure for the passerby, often more often than not. Free boxes typically contain clothes and books, but they can hold anything. The potential magic of strolling through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about, from my perspective, but I am merely one variety of peculiarity among many. Some residents would never consider rummaging through the clothes in a sidewalk box. These individuals engage in goat yoga (yes, yoga with actual goats) or attend Timbers matches (the local soccer team). Portland is filled with people who love all sorts of things. Portland is filled with people who chase their dreams, or dream of chasing their dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug issue. Drug problems often stem from (at their core) mental health issues, and the persistent rain throughout much of the year, coupled with the gloomy clouds, seems to exacerbate the problem. Portland also has a homelessness problem, which no one knows how to address. The homeless population is attracted by Portland's social services, better than in most places, but our services are insufficient, as is the case everywhere. The non-homeless population fluctuates between concern and hostility. In this, we are no different from the rest.

Since the mountain range has been a constant fixture in my life, I've come to understand their significance. The sun's daily ascent and descent is mirrored by their stoic presence, unyielding and unaffected by life's labyrinthine challenges. There are times when I'm consumed by work and life, failing to notice their grandeur, yet even in my most anxious moments, they command my attention. Turning to them, I find solace, their strength providing me with the fortitude to press on. I first encountered these mountains when I began my undergraduate studies, and they've held a special place in my heart since. While the university has its own unique charm, it's the mountains that have always been my true north. The town itself is a delight, with quaint cafes and historic downtown blocks that exude an old-world charm. A short walk or bus ride leads to the library, where the tranquility of the small town awaits, contrasting with the city's energy. This captivating blend of atmospheres invites exploration and creates vivid memories. Whether it's sharing a late-night study break with friends at the park or catching a movie in the cinema, the university makes it easy to create cherished moments. However, the town isn't without its darker memories. The ponds, in particular, have been a frequent companion during times of reflection and crises. As I've watched the wildlife live out their lives, I've pondered my own purpose. One day, I found myself walking north, following the sun's rays as they illuminated the palm trees. There, under the mountains' watchful gaze, I was reminded of my resolve to persevere.

Should you find yourself in Bensonhurst, a densely populated area in Brooklyn, navigating its streets will be a breeze. Public transit is widely available and a preferred mode of travel in the city. Despite its urban character, Bensonhurst retains an unmistakable NYC feel. Expect to encounter an assortment of Asian-owned establishments, a result of a significant influx of Asian residents over the last two decades. These stores, primarily supermarkets and laundromats, are beloved by locals for their superior quality, competitive pricing, and convenience. Nearby, you'll find four Asian markets within a short walk of each other, further enhancing accessibility. While Bensonhurst is not exclusively Asian, it is indeed diverse, with immigrants and their American-born offspring contributing to its vibrant tapestry. Most local businesses are Asian-owned, and the recently renovated park nearby ensures ample recreational opportunities, including basketball, soccer, handball courts, playgrounds, and a children's water fountain.

The neighborhood's residential landscape is characterized by co-op homes and condominiums, with two-family houses being the norm. Despite its generally friendly atmosphere, noise levels can be high, with early morning disturbances from speeding cars and music blaring from passing vehicles. Daytime security is generally good, but nighttime caution is advised due to unpredictable individuals and occasional incidents of package theft and bullying. Personal experiences with bullying and package theft are not uncommon, and dog waste is a persistent issue, with many residents failing to clean up after their pets. Maintaining clean shoes is a practical precaution when navigating Bensonhurst.

The locale I inhabit is bereft of sidewalks. The topography is characterized by a pronounced descent, with my abode perched atop the neighborhood's most precipitous incline, affectionately dubbed the "workout hill" by the jogging enthusiasts who frequent it daily. The absence of sidewalks necessitates that all pedestrians traverse the road, which, despite its patchy condition, is the only viable option. The utility wires, strung along the block, bear the ravages of time and weather, their tattered appearance a testament to the frequent storms that plague our region. The ubiquitous evergreens, though beloved by nature enthusiasts, are seen as a hindrance by many locals, who seek to clear them for a better view of the sea. Consequently, many residences are constructed high on the hill, where glass-fronted second stories afford panoramic vistas of the bay. The sunsets here are spectacular, the water aglow and the sky ablaze with orange hues, though overcast days are more the norm, resulting in a perpetual haze that obscures the sun's rays. Moss, thriving in the damp climate, covers everything from rooftops to automobiles, with my own vehicle having turned a verdant shade after a month's neglect. The neighborhood is predominantly populated by seniors, with children being less common, although the local school is nearby. Dogs, rather than children, are the norm, often seen lounging on lawns or chasing one another down the street. Unattended doors or windows can lead to unexpected canine visitors. Rabbits, of considerable size, roam freely, much to the chagrin of the gardeners, who find their burrowing destructive. My feline companions have taken to hunting them, significantly reducing their numbers. Avian life is abundant, with sparrows, hummingbirds, and the occasional hawk or eagle visible, though the neighborhood's crows often chase them away. The nearest shops are a hike away, but the waterfront offers a few restaurants serving fresh seafood. While the beach is limited, the rocky shore provides ample opportunities for stone throwing, and the bay's relatively narrow width allows for clear views of the opposite shore on most days.

I reside in a typical suburban locale nestled within a small southern Tennessee town. Our neighborhood is situated along the intersection of two state highways, which, while providing connectivity, leads to more vehicle traffic than I'd prefer. Nonetheless, the overall atmosphere remains serene. With minimal turnover in residents, we're familiar with the majority of our neighbors, who primarily engage in routine activities like yard work and daily chores. During winter, we enjoy sledding down our side street. Our home, positioned at the front corner, offers a clear vantage point for observing passersby and their vehicles, especially those unfamiliar to us. Some residents engage in walks, often with their pets, while children play on bikes. We are a family of four - myself, my spouse, and our daughters, aged eleven and fourteen - who frequently work from home, so our comings and goings are well-known. We spend considerable time outdoors, even in inclement weather, and occasionally enjoy grilling on our deck. The neighborhood is replete with trees, a legacy of its former wooded state, leading to abundant shade but also seasonal leaf cleanup. The smell of burning leaves signals the arrival of fall, a season that lately feels prolonged due to mild winters. Our garage, situated at the rear of the house, is our primary entrance unless a visitor calls. I often work there on various projects, particularly my truck, and the open garage doors provide a sense of connection to the neighborhood. Holidays are generally quiet here, except for Thanksgiving and other holidays when families visit from out of town, resulting in increased vehicle presence. Overall, I find our neighborhood to be an agreeable place to reside. The only modification I'd make is to eliminate the thoroughfare, as it would contribute to an even more tranquil atmosphere.

My locality is nestled deep within the high desert, a landscape dominated by nothing but dirt upon dirt. To those who haven't experienced it firsthand, the monotony of perpetual brown and the splendor of a verdant lawn may seem extraordinary. When I resided here in the 90s, homes were dispersed widely, but now, while the pattern remains, new developments have sprouted. This place is gradually transforming into something more akin to a bustling metropolis, though it's fair to say most locales undergo similar changes. Locals are generally cordial, though like any urban environment, it has its ups and downs. My community is particularly notable for its elderly population, lending a certain charm to the neighborhood. Retail options are mostly comprised of chain stores such as Food4Less and Smart & Final, while specialty shops are few and far between. The most prevalent industry here would likely be construction, given the city's limited development and vast swathes of untouched land. This evolution makes me a bit uneasy; I left behind a major city and prefer the stability of my current surroundings. My current livelihood lies in drywall and T-bar installation, a profession that has become commonplace in this rapidly growing town. The wildlife here is another highlight; my children and I have taken to observing and caring for the local lizards and desert insects. The desert's allure brings visitors for various reasons, including the stark beauty of the landscape and the unique ecosystems it harbors. It is essential for residents to learn about the non-human inhabitants to maintain a harmonious coexistence. Attractions are available, with the San Bernardino County Fair being a notable event. Additionally, the nearby town of Wrightwood offers snow-capped mountains and winter sports opportunities. For those interested in the desert's natural history and cultural heritage, the Victor Valley Museum is an excellent choice. It houses geological specimens, paleontological artifacts, and historical objects that illustrate the progression of society and industry in Victorville.

When probed about my locality, my response is likely to be distinctive. Unlike others who might reply, I'm not a typical homeowner with a personal life, but rather a university student residing in a campus environment. My neighborhood, in this context, is the campus community where I live, with my dormitory serving as my primary residence and the campus area encompassing the broader neighborhood, albeit to a lesser degree. Despite this unconventional perspective, there are commonalities with traditional neighborhoods. Both types feature houses, people, stores, and parks. Let's start with the "houses" that populate my neighborhood. Before delving into the types of housing available, clarification is necessary. In my immediate vicinity, there are three main housing types: apartments, standalone homes, and dormitory-style accommodations. Apartments generally house 2-4 people per room, with each floor containing 4-6 rooms. Standard buildings accommodate around 20 residents, on average. Next, there are rental houses available to affiliated individuals, usually alumni, and are typically 2-4 bedrooms. These are less common and scattered throughout the neighborhood. Finally, dormitory rooms, housing hundreds of students, are the most prevalent. Here, two people share a room, with some exceptions. Transitioning to the people, my school's reputation for diversity is evident in my neighborhood's makeup. We have residents from diverse backgrounds and ages. Professional staff mostly live in standalone homes, newer students in dormitories, and older students in apartments. Describing the people in my neighborhood would be an understatement, so let's move on to the stores and parks. As the campus is a self-contained community, it boasts a variety of stores and a single park. These stores offer dining options found elsewhere and the school's unique clothing and grocery stores. This ensures that any need is met within the neighborhood's confines. The park is a shared space for the diverse residents, maintained clean and safe by everyone.

In my decade-long residence here, I've had varied experiences, some sorrowful, some joyful. Initially, transitioning from Riverdale to Stockbridge was emotionally challenging. However, my parents, ever considerate, sought a better environment for our family. Our new neighborhood offered improved housing and schooling, though initially, it felt odd. Over time, I adapted, forging friendships and, admittedly, a few rivalries. The neighborhood's labyrinthine layout, once daunting, is now navigable with GPS, allowing for deeper exploration.

My neighbors, though distant, have been kind. Mr. Glen and his family, and Dennis, were particularly neighborly. I fondly recall attending Mr. Glen's nuptials, a joyous affair where I was the impromptu bouquet catcher. I've lost touch with Marsharii, one of Glen's daughters, but wish her well.

The neighborhood is a playground for my hobbies. I've spent countless hours here, from video gaming with friends to solitary nature escapes. My love for balance and swordplay is nurtured by practice sessions with a bokken in our favorite park. The tennis and basketball courts, though untouched for years, remain inviting. My father and Mr. Graves' influence on tennis has left lasting memories. Life here has been a journey of joy, and I eagerly anticipate the stories yet to unfold.

The locale of my residence is proximate to the educational institution at which I am enrolled, a circumstance I find advantageous. The neighborhood predominantly consists of multi-unit dwellings, yet it offers a variety of dining and socializing venues without incurring exorbitant costs. Recently, one such establishment underwent a name change and, while it has seen an uptick in pricing, the service and libations remain satisfactory. The inhabitants are a pleasant lot, primarily comprising students and individuals with modest incomes, drawn to the affordable accommodations. An elementary school lies close by, adding to the neighborhood's familial atmosphere. My neighbors and I maintain a cordial distance, though the building's management has installed an air freshener unit near a residence to neutralize frequent cannabis use, an amusing, if not slightly offensive, solution. The buildings surrounding my abode exhibit a blend of old-world charm and modern-day renovations, while new constructions down the road, though less appealing aesthetically, command high rents. A nearby eatery serves dishes on paper plates and microwaves its wares, accompanied by a gas station nearby, reputed to be less than ideal for employment. Recently, city funding has led to an improvement in the road infrastructure, enhancing the area's ambiance. My apartment complex is partially obscured by trees, with a few stumps where others once stood. Behind my building lies a verdant tree line and another set of apartments, while 43rd Street, immediately adjacent, presents a stark contrast with its dilapidated sidewalks and shabby structures. Crime has, unfortunately, been an issue in the neighborhood, with several apartment complexes being hotspots. Nevertheless, I find the area affordable and well-serviced, with the university within walking distance and accessible bus stops nearby.

I reside in a neighborhood comprised of duplexes strategically situated on a cul-de-sac. These homes, each adorned with a distinct yellow hue, pristine white porches, and verdant metal roofs, are arranged in a way that they appear as individual dwellings. While most of the inhabitants are acquaintances, not all are on friendly terms. At dusk, we gather at the end of an indefinite driveway, engaging in casual conversation while the neighborhood's youth enjoy their toys, sidewalk chalk, or kite-flying. It's a refreshing respite from our modern, technology-dominated world, almost like stepping back in time. Our community is surrounded by expansive fields and trees, often graced by clear blue skies and fluffy white clouds. This season, we've encountered tornado warnings, with last night's storm bringing actual sirens. I found myself in my bathtub, clutching my smallest dog, purse, and pillows, while my larger dog remained in the living room, anxious and barking. The neighborhood was deserted, save for the sound of hail pounding the ground. Post-storm, the road was billowing with steam from the temperature shift, from 92°F to 75°F in minutes. The hail instantly melted upon hitting the scorching pavement. As the skies cleared, a rainbow materialized, prompting me to snap photos to share with my loved ones. The streets remained tranquil for an hour before residents returned from their storm-evacuation destinations. Life resumed its usual rhythm, with mothers and children outside while dinner cooked. This small-town feel is a delight for a recent transplant from New Hampshire to North Carolina. My two-bedroom, two-bath apartment is identical to my neighbors' on the outside, but the interiors vary in size. I enjoy strolling through the largest field behind my home, heading to the non-swimmer's pond where I've spotted deer and heard the morning serenade of giant bullfrogs. It's a wonderful place to reside, just forty minutes from Charlotte. Each morning is greeted by roosters' crowing from the nearby farms, adding to the rural ambiance. Evenings are marked by the distant braying of a donkey at a neighboring farm. I was fortunate to find this charming neighborhood.

In the heart of my eighth-grade year, I relocated to this residential area. Initially, integrating was challenging, yet I eventually connected with individuals dwelling nearby - one just two houses away and another residing on the same street. Though they've since moved, fond recollections linger. Most original inhabitants remain, preserving the essence of this suburban haven. The neighborhood is replete with two-story dwellings; weekends echo with young voices engaged in outdoor play. Daily life is tranquil, and neighbors are trustworthy. Package delivery is safe here, and I've never experienced any conflicts. A nearby park holds cherished memories, from organized sports to impromptu games with cousins' children. Though I once sustained an injury, the positive experiences far surpass the unpleasant ones. The park's allure has evolved; now it's a sanctuary for childhood reminiscences. My neighborhood is a mosaic of cultures, offering various culinary delights within a short radius. While many opt for delivery, diverse cuisines are easily accessible. Essential stores dot the area, including dry cleaners, pharmacies, and a grocery store. An Indian-owned store caters to those seeking authentic flavors. Overall, my neighborhood is a blessing amidst news of distressing experiences elsewhere.

In the heart of South Carolina lies a modest community, unremarkable in its appearance yet pivotal in the state's agriculture scene. Johnston, self-proclaimed as the Peach Capital of the World, wears its agricultural heritage with pride, evident in the lush peach orchards and sprawling cattle fields that dominate the landscape. Houses, while scattered and often set back from the road, maintain a quaint charm with their two-story frames and roofs that either gleam silver under the summer sun or blend subtly into the gray hues of the shingles. The town's nucleus, a mere four-way intersection, is home to the sole commercial district, housing a trio of establishments: Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese eatery; Fiesta, a vibrant Mexican restaurant; and Gary's, a humble burger joint. A defunct pizzeria now haunts the memory of the townsfolk, replaced by the sweet allure of Cherry Coca-Cola at Maxwell and Halford Drug. The grocery scene is limited to a small, pricey store called IGA, and a bustling Dollar General that stocks a vast array of necessities. A single furniture store, Possibilities Furniture & More, caters to the locals' needs, as does a pet grooming service, Clark's Cuts and Kennels. Medical care is provided by clinics situated on the town's outskirts, and education begins at Johnston Elementary School, which serves students through fifth grade before they journey to neighboring towns for middle and high school. The community's recreational options are modest, with plans underway to create a 2.5-acre recreational area. Despite its limitations, Johnston's small size and close-knit community make it a welcoming, if overlooked, gem.

First encountering my residence was while tuning into a podcast about persons gone astray. The revelation was unexpected. Nearly all abodes in this zone exceeded a thousand dollars monthly. The narrative eluded me and my companions. Perhaps it's the grind. Some friends often weep into their pillows at night. Expenses are high, yet frugality has become our modus operandi over time. The dusty aroma of antique toys and vintage attire grows familiar. Scent in adulthood tends to diminish. Picking up a habit, such as smoking, or simply acclimating to the status quo is common. However, the flea market remains steadfast. The smell of adulthood lingers, pervading the leather and even surviving after washing. Here, three thrift stores are within walking distance. Beginning at the far end, one can visit two charity shops, a library, a rare bookstore, and a curio shop. The downtown area bustles with traffic and pedestrians each morning, but the thrift stores remain serene. Uninterrupted by the city's commotion, they offer a peaceful haven for the day. Yearly, the population increases, and with it, the number of thrift stores. This burgeoning metropolis, home to one of the world's largest e-commerce and delivery hubs, is still experiencing growing pains. It echoes New York's energy, where everyone pursues their goals individually, with little expectation for interaction. Solitude is acceptable here, unlike in the South, where concern is taken as caring. Privacy is respected, allowing one to maintain their personal space as desired. The city moves like a tide, washing over and receding, leaving each to their own pursuits. The building next door's pianist and our upstairs vocalists contribute to the city's symphony. Our community comes together for various occasions, from birthdays to funerals, offering support as needed. I'm fortunate to call this place home. Most neighbors are pleasant, and they reciprocate my kindness. I ensure cleanliness and leave treats, and they do the same for me. I help with mail, and they return the favor. It's enjoyable seeing them, and I believe they appreciate my presence as much as I value theirs. Living in a sprawling, impersonal modernist complex, it's the people around me that make me feel I haven't entirely squandered my life.

The locale where I reside is a quintessential example of the cookie-cutter suburban life. The neighborhood's presence of a homeowner's association (HOA) is quite evident from the moment of entry, showcasing a uniform landscape of well-tended single-family dwellings. The front yards exhibit a consistent pattern, with a small swath of landscaped grass, decorative pebbles, and petite driveways punctuated by occasional trees. Each residence boasts a two-car garage, a testament to the HOA's obsession with uniformity. The roads are pristine, sans potholes, and the properties are predominantly single-story, though two-story abodes occasionally dot the landscape. Mail delivery is managed through a communal setup, with a large, secure mailbox cluster at the end of the street, accessed via key. There's also a pair of larger lockers for package deliveries. My neighborhood straddles the line between rural and suburban, with ample land for various communal facilities. Residents enjoy access to multiple well-maintained community pools and extensive walking trails, eliminating the need to venture far for exercise. The demographic is a mix of retirees, middle-aged, and young professionals coexisting harmoniously in a safe and cohesive environment. The city, while large by population, retains a small-town feel. Essentials are within reach, including a compact yet sufficient mall. A 15-minute drive leads to a plethora of shopping options, from high-end grocery stores to bargain outlets. Overall, my neighborhood is a tranquil, well-maintained, and typical suburban haven, complete with amenities like pools and walking trails, and a mere car ride away from shopping necessities.

Nestled at the edge of a bustling metropolis, my hometown is a small Midwestern town that sits just beyond the suburban sprawl. My immediate vicinity, located on the eastern flank, is the town's most economically distressed district. Here, property values are low, with many dwellings rented or owned by low-income residents. Despite the economic climate, the area is far from unpleasant. Neighbors are typically warm and welcoming, with greetings exchanged readily. While crime rates are marginally higher, they remain relatively low, save for a few isolated incidents in recent years.暴力犯罪, including shootings and one reported homicide, have occurred within a close radius. My neighbors lost their son in an incident outside a nearby watering hole last year. Our household has remained relatively untouched by criminal activity, save for a few minor incidents. The opioid epidemic has cast a dark shadow over our community, claiming many lives due to fentanyl overdoses. Nevertheless, resources exist to combat this issue, including rehabilitation facilities and training sessions. Despite these challenges, our town boasts several positive attributes. My son's elementary school is particularly commendable, with dedicated staff ensuring an inclusive environment for all students, even those with special needs. The school's positivity is complemented by an active parent-teacher organization, which hosts numerous events to foster family involvement and educational growth. Given that over 20% of the town's population resides below the poverty line, the school offers free breakfast and lunch to all students, eliminating food insecurity. No child or family is singled out due to their financial status, with school fees and supplies being affordable. Recent improvements have been made by the City Council and staff, such as road repairs, landscaping, and park refurbishments. These enhancements, however, have primarily benefited the town's center and western sectors, where commercial activity is concentrated. The eastern side, where I reside, has been relatively overlooked, leading to some local discontent. Despite these perceived inequities, I find living here quite enjoyable. The people are generally kind, the schools are excellent, shopping options are abundant, and our home, though modest, is comfortable. We've called this town home for over a decade and a half, and we can't picture ourselves living anywhere else.

My locale is suffused with an atmosphere of culture. Nestled atop a slope, encircled by edifices steeped in history. I reside in a multi-story apartment complex that is a stone's throw from a historic theater, and a short stroll away from a vibrant arcade bar that draws diverse patrons on balmy summer evenings. Lines can often be seen stretching around the block on weekends in June and July. A bit farther up the hill lies the nearest urban park, expansive given its locale, rimmed by concrete and elevated steps. Through the frigid winter months, homeless individuals often set up their shelters in neat rows alongside the sidewalk and steps, using proximity to keep warm. The mid-winter downpours can be intense, making warmth a challenge. Surrounding the center of town rather than the outskirts, they are near the sole family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. While the historical grandeur of the architecture and the stately buildings that dot the various levels of the rolling hills descending towards the sea are undeniable, what truly captivates me about my neighborhood is the spirit of the people. Hilltop, once notorious for gang violence, still echoes with stories of federal interventions three decades past. The people here, though the neighborhood is still considered rough, strive to maintain a sense of community. The admonition to avoid the Hill at night, especially for those perceived as white, carries a lingering scent of prejudice. Perhaps it's because I can blend in enough to not be totally white, or maybe Hilltop accepts me as one of their own, a person acutely aware of the persistent reminders of racial and cultural conditioning. No matter how far I venture, Hilltop remains home. Walking its streets at night, I've encountered more kindness than danger. I've had a stranger offer me their coat to ward off the cold, and even in the gloomiest conditions, I've received unexpected gestures of kindness, like having someone stop and hand me a few dollars, telling me I am valuable.

In the heart of rural America, specifically the serene landscapes of small-town Michigan, I've made my home. Nestled between expansive farmlands and quaint tourist destinations, I reside in a locale that eschews the trappings of big-city life. The nearest shopping center is a drive away, as are the popular retail chains and eateries. Yet, amidst this rural setting, I am surrounded by natural beauty. Lake Michigan stretches out on one side, while Lake Charlevoix gracefully complements it on the other. Virtually every turn offers an opportunity to dip one's toes in the water.

My neighborhood embodies the essence of small-town living. Houses here are not clustered together but rather spaced out, each with its unique character. Many are older homes, some updated, some steadfast in their original charm. Basements, a staple in this region, are often visible from the street. Aluminum siding adorns many homes, painted in a kaleidoscope of colors. Yards are well-maintained, filled with trampolines, play structures, gardens, and fences for pets. This community reflects the sturdy, hardworking spirit of Middle America. Children play freely in the streets, and neighbors often acknowledge each other with friendly waves or nods. The lawns are neatly trimmed, and homes are well-cared for, creating a peaceful and safe atmosphere.

Despite its unassuming appearance, my neighborhood is well-served by local amenities. The county sheriff's department and health department are nearby, as is the city's recycling center. Baseball and softball fields, complete with enthusiastic announcers, are a stone's throw away from our homes. Our small-town airport is adjacent, its small planes a common sound in the background. A local ice cream parlor is within walking distance, and downtown is just a bike ride away for the adventurous. Our neighborhood park is mere blocks away, making it a convenient destination for family outings. All in all, it is an exceptional place to call home, offering the tranquility and safety that many seek.

original_texts:
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
The first thing you have to understand about Portland, Oregon is the definition of "weird". The unofficial town slogan, on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on at least half of these endeavors, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a small cry to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less known and less expensive, generating creative and unique subcultures. To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
If you are planning on visiting Bensonhurt, Brooklyn, you will not have a difficult time finding it! Public transportation is very accessible and is one of the most popular forms of transportation in New York City. Bensonhurt is a fairly urban neighborhood, so you will still feel as if you are in New York City. During your visit, be prepared to see the various Asian stores all around. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurt has received an influx of Asian inhabitants. Because of this, you will see an Asian-owned store at least every block as you are walking. Most popular are supermarkets and laundromats. Coincidentally, these businesses are very popular among local residents, as quality of food in the supermarkets are superb, the prices are much cheaper, and finally yet importantly, it is very convenient. Just nearby where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within two minutes of walking distance from each other. This just adds to the convenience of accessing grocery. I’m not saying Bensonhurst is purely populated by Asian inhabitants, though. It is quite diverse all around, with immigrants and their first-generation and second-generation American children here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the local area are Asian owned. In addition to these Asian owned businesses, there is also a recently renovated park nearby, which has around ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for kids to enjoy water in the summer. Since we are in New York City, of course the parks are very diverse. You will see all sorts of diversity here, able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren’t many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you’d find are ones for co-op living, or condominium apartments. The majority of living spaces here are two-family houses though. Most of the people are quite nice, however, very noisy. Every day, you’d hear cars blasting their music as they drive by your house, or constantly flooring the gas on their cars which will wake you up in the morning. If you are planning on visiting during night time, you should be on your guard. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people are unpredictable. You may run into people who want to start trouble for no reason, bullies and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past via physical assault, but this was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package stealing. Although a common thing, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, although New York City has a fine for people not cleaning up after their dogs, people don’t follow the rules here. Every morning, you will see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station, or on your way to the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the floor everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!
There aren't many sidewalks where I live. Everything seems to flow downward, and my house sits right at the crest of the steepest hill in the neighborhood. People call it the "work out hill" because so many joggers like to run up it during their daily work out. As there aren't any sidewalks at all on my street everyone walks on the road. There road is pitted in a few places and can feel a bit hazardous to drive on. Some of the telephone and electric wires strung up around the block at tattered looking. It rains and storms a lot in our area, so branches and other debris often strike down the power lines and the constant repairs make them look checkered and patchwork-y. There's many tall evergreen trees all around everywhere you look. But people here hate the trees. They strive to cut down as many as possible because the trees obstruct the view of the ocean. That's why many of the houses are built so high up on the hill, with huge glass-fronted second stories that loom up one after the other to take in the view of the bay. It's gorgeous around sunset when the water seems to get lit up from below and the sky turns orange. It's cloudy more often than not, though, so you end up seeing most of the sunlight through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows on everything it can: roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked out in my driveway for a month and when I went out to use it, it had turned green and furry with moss. Took me three hours to scrap it all off. There aren't that many children around where I live, though there's a school only a few blocks away. Most of the people in my neighborhood are older, many of them retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs. It's common to see them sitting out in people's lawns or racing down the street after each other. If you leave a door or window open you risk having them sneak into your house. I found one once in my living room and had to shoo it back out the front door. Rabbits run wild around the area. Some of them are good sized, and the gardeners hate them because the dig up the roots of plants and burrow into people's lawns. My cats love them though, and have hunted most of them out of our neighborhood. We also get the usual assortment of birds: small sparrows and hummingbirds, and the occasional hawk or eagle sometimes swoops by until the neighborhood crows chase it off. There aren't any stores around, but if you hike downhill to the waterfront there's a few restaurants that serve fresh seafood. There isn't much of a beach down there, but the rocks along the shore are fun to hurl into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide. You can see the opposite shoreline clearly even through the mist on most days.
I live in a typical suburb area in a small southern town in Tennessee. It's a connecting street between two state highways, so we get a bit more traffic on the street than I'd like, but other than that, it's a quiet neighborhood. There's not too many folks that move in and out, so I've grown used to most of the people that live in the neighborhood. People busy themselves with yard work and other daily chores for the most part. In the winter, we sled down a hill on our side street. We live in a house at the front corner of our street, so we see everyone coming and going all day long and are familiar with the cars that people drive around here. Whenever we see a strange vehicle, we tend to take note of it. Some of the neighbors go walking for exercise or just to walk their dogs. Kids play on their bikes and all that you would expect from that. We are at home a lot since we work from our house. There are four of us, Myself and my Wife, and two Daughters ages eleven and fourteen. So, I'd say that everyone else is used to us coming and going as well. We get outside and play, sometimes even in the rain. Once in a while we grill outside on our back deck and it's always a pleasant smell from the barbecue and all. It seems that there's always someone cutting grass around here and you can hear a lawn mower nearly every day from March through about October, when the grass finally stops growing. We have a lot of trees in our neighborhood as it was originally a wooded area, so there's lots of shade, but there's always a lot of leaves in the Fall as well. So, that means raking and burning the leaves on a yearly basis. I like the smell of burning leaves too, so that's always a nice sign that Fall has arrived. Lately, we've not been having much Winter to speak of, so it just feels like a long Fall. Our garage is at the back of our house, so we seldom use the front door of our house unless someone knocks on the door, which is rare. I like to work in the garage on my truck or other projects from time to time and when I have the garage doors open, it feels like I'm more tuned into the neighborhood. On holidays it is pretty quiet around here. Thanksgiving sees some of the neighborhood families visiting with people from out of town and there are extra cars parked everywhere during that time of year. It's the same at other holidays like Mother's day and Christmas. All in all, I like living here. If it weren't a through street, it would be perfect.
My neighborhood is in the smack middle of the high desert, where there is dirt, dirt and more dirt. Unless someone has actually experienced living here, they probably donâ€™t really understand the feeling of always seeing brown , and when you do see a lawn, you know that person is spending a fortune on lawn care. When I first lived here in the 90s, houses were spread out far and wide. Now it is pretty much the same way by there are a lot of new additions. Honestly this place looks more and more like a city everyday, but supposed most places are changing the same way. Most of the time the people are very friendly, but just like any city you have your good parts and bad. In my neighborhood I'm surrounded by friendly old people iI guess it's a nicer neighborhood. The stores in this place are pretty much the store who have chains, like food for less and smart and final. If you want uscale you have to travel I never really see any whole foods or stores of that nature. The jobs that are most prominent in my city I would say not based on any official demographics, is construction. I think this is on account of this city is still not very developed, there is still a lot of wide open spaces to build. That kind of scares me, I like things the way they are now. I left a big city and I'm not keen on going back. Speaking of construction this was the field my full time job is located in, i am a drywall and T-bar instalator. What I like about my home is the different animals. People come to the high desert for many reasons, not the least of which is the stark beauty of the desert itself. High desert climate and topography have created challenging ecosystems which need protecting and which are home to different types of wildlife. Human residents of the high desert should take the time to learn about the non-human residents who share this environment in order to co-exist safely and harmoniously. My family and I have adapted very well to the wildlife. I have three children and they are all obsessed with lizards and dessert bugs, as I am writing this now they are outside trying to catch different specimens. As far as attractions goes we have some. Additionally, Victorville is a good place for families to experience the desert. It can generate a different experience. If you can, plan your visit to coincide with its annual event: the San Bernardino County Fair. The fair will enrich your visit with the right mix of activities and fun the Victorville way. Pop by the nearby Wrightwood to see the snow covered mountains and take some winter sports lessons to finish out your visit. Interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert ecosystem? The Victor Valley Museum includes geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of the development of society and industry of Victorville.
When asked to describe my neighborhood, I'm sure that my answer is somewhat unique. While others who respond to this are most likely homeowners with their own individual lives, my situation is a tad bit different. I consider my neighborhood to be the college campus that I stay on, and the people that live in my dormitory to be my community. I also consider the surrounding campus to be my neighborhood, albeit to a lesser extent. Despite this peculiarity, my neighborhood shares some commonalities with the more conventional ideas about a neighborhood. Just like any conventional neighborhood, the neighborhood I stay in has houses, people, stores and parks. Let us begin by discussing the "houses" that comprise my neighborhood. Before I begin to explore the houses in my neighborhood, it would be best to clarify the types of house that can be found in my neighborhood. There are three types of housing in my immediate vicinity, the apartments, the actual houses, and the dormitory houses. First, In the apartments, there are usually between 2-4 people in any given room, and there are about 4-6 rooms on each floor. The most common building type can house about 2 floors, so on average, there are 20 or so people living in each building. Second, are the actual houses that are available for anyone with an affiliation to the school to rent. Typically these are 2-4 bedroom setups that usually have alumni living in them. However, there are only a handful of these types of houses spread throughout the neighborhood, as they are less efficient. Finally, there are the typical dorm rooms which house 100's of students. In these, you have two people sharing a room with some exception, and it is the most common type of housing in my neighborhood. With housing covered we are ready to move on to the people. My school prides itself on diversity and this is reflected in the makeup of my neighborhood. There are people from all cultures and ages that live in my neighborhood. Most of the professional staff live in the houses that are placed in the neighborhood, whereas the newer students stay in the dormitory style housing and the older students stay in the apartment-style housing. The people in this neighborhood can't be done justice by simply talking about them, so it would be best to simply move on to the stores and parks in my neighborhood. Since my school really is it's own self-contained neighborhood, it has a plethora of stores and a single park. The stores are a mix of dining options that would be found in any other neighborhood, and the schools own unique brand of clothing and grocery stores. As such, anything that is needed can be found within my neighborhood's boundaries! Additionally, the park in my neighborhood is a playground for all the diverse people in my neighborhood, it is kept clean and free of crime by all the members of my neighborhood!
Well, considering that I’ve been here for about 10 years, I guess I can share what I know. First off, I was pretty sad when I first came to my neighborhood. I came from Riverdale to Stockbridge, and I’m not going to lie, I cried, because I missed them and I loved them.. but my mom and dad wanted the best for me and my little sister, so we moved to a better location for housing, a better high school, everything was considered “not ghetto” when we moved to our new neighborhood. Throughout the years, I got used to it, and made some new friends, and some new enemies too in school. I never really truly got to know my neighbors throughout the years, except Mr. Glen and his children, as well as Dennis for a bit, both being right next to us. They have been enjoyable people that I almost can consider as family in some ways, and I truly do appreciate them. I remember when me, mom, dad, and my sister went to Mr. Glen’s wedding (They got re-married) It was really fun and enjoyable to say the least, and something I’m looking forward to someday, as I build my wealth and give my future wife the life of a Queen. When Mr. Glen’s wife, Ms. Veda, took off the white little strap on her leg and threw it, I caught it! Sadly I didn’t catch the flowers! We all danced the night away, and I really enjoyed having a good time with Marsharii, one of their daughters. I haven’t seen her since though. I hope she’s moved on to bigger and better things. The neighborhood itself is like a maze, although now I have a GPS, so I can take more time to explore it. I’ve only went so far, and that is when I’ve hung out with my friends Kason and Curtis. We all used to play video games alot, and just enjoy life to the fullest as much as we could. Sometimes I would go to the park and enjoy nature, which soothes my soul. It gives me a sense of calmness and peace these days. I’ll also bring some sticks that I bought from home depot and just practice my balance, And bring my bokken wooden sword if I can,. I have fun enjoying what I love to do. There’s also a basketball and tennis court, although I haven’t played tennis or basketball in a long time, It’s still nice to have in case I ever want to pick it back up and give it another go. My dad grew me and my best friend up on Tennis with Mr. Graves, and we’d always have a great time.. They worked us hard! But we always had fun. I guess there’s a lot of times I’ve had fun in this neighborhood, and there’s plenty of stories, but these are what really stuck out to me, and I believe that the best, is yet to come!
My neighborhood is nearby to the college that I attend, and for that I quite enjoy living there. There are mostly apartment buildings, but a few restaurants and bars that are fun to go to and aren't terribly expensive to go to. One of the bars was just renamed, and that one is more expensive to go to but it isn't really the worst quality of service or drinks there. Most of the people are nice. They are either college kids or they are lower income, since the apartment housing isn't very expensive. There's a lot of children nearby since there is an elementary school within walking distance of my apartment. I don’t know my neighbors, but I don’t really want to. They smoke a lot of weed and so the management of my building put an air freshener unit right across from their door, which my boyfriend and I found very funny. It’s almost insulting. The buildings that are around me are usually pretty old looking but might have renovated interiors. Down the street a bit there are brand new apartments, but I don’t like them because I know the construction done on them wasn’t particularly good. They’re cheaply built but the rent is expensive, which I think is such a scam but because they’re near campus, the management of those buildings can get away with it. There is a really cheap restaurant about five minutes from where I live that serves food only on paper plates and most of what they make is microwaved. Then across from that is a gas station, which I’ve heard isn’t a very good place to work. But thanks to some money from the city, the road was redone last summer so that there’s a nice big sidewalk, lots of grass on the medians and sides of the roads, and now the area is a little nicer. But the apartment building I live in is shrouded in tress. They cut a few of them down, so there are a few stumps, but there are a lot more trees where I live than down the road. Behind my apartment complex is a tree line and then another set of apartments. I live on 42nd street, but right behind is 43rd street and that one isn’t as nice. The sidewalks are really bad and falling apart, and most of the buildings on it look shabby. There are a lot of trees on this street, but that is probably to hide what the buildings look like. Most of the crime in my area has happened at an apartment complex on that street, but then again, I can’t blame just them. There are apartments across the street from me that also have a lot of crime and a rather transient population. But I think I like where I live. I can afford it, and there’s plenty of useful amenities nearby. I especially like how the university is within walking distance and there are two bus stops so that I can get to the store and downtown with ease.
My neighborhood is made up of duplex's on a cul-de-sac. They are intermittently placed and spaced so that they look like individual houses. The only difference is each is painted yellow with white porches and green metal roofs. Almost everyone, but not all, are friends with each other. We stand at the end of a not pre-decided driveway some evenings and chit chat while the small children of the neighborhood play with their toys, sidewalk chalk or fly their kites. It is very refreshing in this modern all to mechanical/computer filled world. It is rather like stepping back in time. We are surrounded by fields and trees enhanced by blue skies and white billowing clouds. The only downfall? This season, we are experiencing tornado warnings and for the first time, last night we actually heard actual tornado sirens so we had to head towards shelter. Sure enough, you would have found me in my bathtub clutching my littlest dog along with my purse and a few pillows. My big dog wanted nothing to do with the bathroom and remained in the livingroom, nervous and barking, nervous about the odd circumstances. The neighborhood was quiet except for the sound of large hail which fell all bout the ground. After the storm the road literally was steaming from the change of temperature. We went from 92 to 75 in a matter of minutes. The hail immediately melted when it hit the hot pavement. As I looked up towards the clearing skies, the sun came out and it started to rain. A double rainbow apparated. I ran into the house and grabbed my camera. Quickly snapped pictures to share with my Facebook friends and family. They were in awe, as was I. The streets remained quiet for another hour, before some people finally came home from wherever they were when the thunderstorm hit. Then it was business as usual, mom’s and children outside as dinner cooked. Such a friendly neighborhood for this gal who has recently moved form NH to NC. I adore the southern accent that people speak with. I have a two bedroom and two bath apartment, as does everyone. Though all the houses look the same on the outside, not all of the apartments are the same on the inside. Some are actually quite tiny. It doesn’t make sense to me.
